I have no idea if something like this is even printable with no support, and even so - the support may be stronger than the fragile wing.  I will give the tip a flat foot to stand on.  Printing vertically may be the only way forward.

Whats more fun that a construction toy used for... well... construction!
This excavator shovel has 2 short rod pivots on each side allowing for tilt control or rigid positioning options.
The walls of the piece are 2mm thick for strength, and the whole thing prints on it's back with no raft or support needed.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.35mm layer, 0.5mm nozzle

Infill:

20%
I needed to run a file around the end of the rods to clear up some burs but all in all the print came out perfectly usable.

I used sketchup and started with a hexagon which I sliced in halve and extruded to amke the scoop.
I added the rods and digging teeth later.
This is actually my 3rd design iteration as I imported some of the pieces from the thinkfun construction sets into sketchup so I could make sure the design had enough clearance between the mounting rods to allow it to work.
My first sketches had a more curved look but I found this tended to need support and while it matched actual excavator scoops perfectly it did not "look" right. The hard edged design is more instantly recognisable and is an easier print.

description.text:
This is a simple snap-together frame to allow for viewing of 120 film stereographic slides. There are several (hard-to-find) patterns in the wild, but this is modeled after the common 80 X 140 mm size.  This has 54mm square apertures with a 63mm spacing. 
There are several plates, something for the smallest to largest print beds. 
Both sides are symmetrical, and are intended to be either glued or taped together, sandwiching the slides in between. Beware, super glues (cyanoacrylates) often precipitate a difficult-to-remove white haze. You DON'T want it on your slide film. 
Look for the terraPin 2HT Stereo Pinhole Camera in the future!

3D printable spray paint stencil, demonstrating bridging parts of the stencil together in a way that allows for underspray to do things that you couldn't with a conventional spray paint stencil.

I printed mine on my old Lulzbot AO-100, because of its removable print bed.  Printed in PLA, and then threw the bed in the freezer for a few minutes to pop the part off without damaging the bridges.  
For best results, use a spray adhesive to hold the stencil to the surface you're enhancing, and add some masking tape around the perimeter.  Work quickly so that the spray adhesive doesn't dry before you're done.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

No

Infill:

20%

Notes: Rotate part, to orientation where no overhangs are necessary

I wanted to design something a little less than ordinary without going too extreme. In the process I was inspired by a random object on my desk; a 25 watt oven lamp.  
There is no proper orientation. Either the flat surface or the rounded surface can be the top/bottom. The entrance piece can be rotated to suit. I purposefully made it thick, so when printed (in my case 2 perimeters, 10% infill) it would act as two walls with a near hollow cavity for insulation.  
Final image shows a 40% scaled print and a partial full scale print for sizing and fitting.

Print:
3 x Clips
1 x Entrance
1 x Large Round Half
1 x Flat OR Small Round Half The entrance piece will need support to print and the rounded pieces may require support (better to be on the safe side). Little clean up required. Fit together and snap the clips into place. Tweet tweet.

Someone said V-12 and I heard you! This one is very simmilar to my V-8 but with the addition of a modular section that allows you to make any size; want a V-24? no problem, want a V-6 ? You got it! Perhaps something strange like an in line-8 or 6...weird! Motor on demand!
There is a complete single tray file for those who have the printer footprint for it other wise single part types per tray for colour printing and I have added the source file so you can play, enjoy!
I am printing one today (started 11:30 am Sunday) I will have pictures tonight!  
All done! 7.5-8 hours of printing time and 15-20 minutes to assemble.
UPDATE I have added a larger piston. It should fit a bit tighter but requires good settings.

Skeinforge settings were; 0.3 layer height, 1 extra shell, 100% infill, reverse on for 75-78 ms. This allowed for strong manipulatable parts.
Print each tray in your desired colour
Assemble the pistons and connectors small end with 3mm filament
Assemble the baddest ass crank shaft ever! It is symmetrical based off a center link piece, just be sure to put the pistons on as you go two per space (leave the end pins out till last)
Put your desired linear cylinder configurations together with hot glue, acetone, melting what ever works for you; I like Krazy glue (it's crazy with a K!) Don't glue it in the V configuration yet! You wont be able to get the piston/crank assembly in other wise.
Slide the entire piston/crank assembly in one side of the cylinder assembly then the other.
Glue it together in the V configuration. Take note of the rounded corner, that is meant to be the finished edge.
Once the glue has dried insert the rotation pins in the ends of the crank shaft
then the crank handle
Rev it up!

comments.text: I also noticed the crank was a little weak, and broke a lot. Also, it was grouped into four pins, but a v12 would have 6 crank pins and 2 pistons per pin, the two pistons on the pin would be on opposite banks, and the angle of the V would be 60 degrees. I would say make the connection between the parts in the cranks shorter (so they only have two pistons each,) and make the rings that wrap around the crank thicker, then just make more.

title: Rostock Max v2 Greg´s Wade´s Mount

description.text:
Mounting braket for using a geared extruder (Namely this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379/) on the Rostock Max v2.
The original EZStruder got problems regarding lost steps at high extrusion rates.
I also added a modifyed 5 mm longer guidler because on the original one the screws were slipping off after some time printing.

Cutting M5 thread After printing the main body you need to get a 4,2 mm drill bit and cut about 8 mm into to bottom filament hole. Now get an M 5 tap and cut the required threads for the pneumatic push in fitting to carry the PTFE-Bowden-Tubing.

Designed with Autodesk Fusion 360 This was the first design I ever did in Autodesk Fusion 360 (ADF360) At first I downloaded the Open Source laser cut files from SeeMeCNC´s GitHub repository:
https://github.com/seemecnc/RostockMAXv2/tree/master/CAD_FILES/Lasercut%20Files/REV1
From here I was able to import the .dxf turn it into a sketch and extrude it. Now I got the .stl of the main body of the Greg´s Wade´s Reloaded extruder.
http://www.thingiverse.com/download:63661
In ADF360 I transformed the mesh into a solid (sort of) by clicking on "mesh to BRep"
Afterwards I inserted a random Nema 17 from GrabCAD into the assembly. Here I arranged everything in 3D, using joints where possible.
Now began the fun part (literally), all I had to do was projecting corners and planes into a new component, extrude and refine a bit. I took me 6h to make this little braked... but I had never really worked with ADF360 before, the joints part alone took me an hour to understand.
I'am convinced that I could do the part again in less than an hour. ADF360 is really awesome and you should give it a try, for the hobbyist it's free so check it out.

Extruder Settings I changed the following:
-Acceleration from: 6500 to 750 mm/s² (the polar moment of inertia is way higher now)
-Steps/mm from: 92,3 to 868 (did fit my hobbed bolt, your settings may vary) Retractions are still a problem, I get lost steps at speeds higher than 23mm/s but these settings work reasonably well for the moment:
Speed: 23 mm/s
Distance: 4,5 mm

description.text: One of my few tf2 models in the making. I recommend printing in white then painting it until i make a snap together version. Enjoy!

These disks will hold up to thirteen 3 mm or seven 5 mm LEDs. They have tabs on the side that you can use to mount them to whatever you like.  They are designed so that you can press-fit the LEDs, requiring no adhesive or fasteners.  They were designed as part of our (i3 Detroit) "Squiggly Trike" entry in the Red Bull Creation challenge in NYC last July.

These a simple, one-piece designs.  You may need to tweak the sizing, so the design and GCode files are provided.  I found that they had to be scaled up about 20% on the Makerbot we were given to use.  The sizing you use will depend upon the printer and material you are using.  Once you're done making it, just push the LEDs into the holes.  Then you'll need to solder the anodes or cathodes together to fit your power supply or other drivers.  We drove these with an Arduino (Freakduino Chibi) through a MOSFET because of the current required to drive so many LEDs at once.

title: Anti Wobble Z Nut Mount for Lulzbot Taz 4 or 5 Printers

description.text: This project is aimed at eliminating the minor Z banding or Z wobble you may encounter when printing with the stock Taz 4 or Taz 5 printers. This is a bolt on upgrade, no firmware or frame modifications are required. Build thread is here: https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=2476 Video with more information about the unit is available here: https://youtu.be/yokdL-T7lW4 Edit 1: Uploaded new files. The bearing holder now has the correct size feet. The changes to the other two parts are mostly cosmetic to address reports of issues with the STL's. if you have previously successfully printed the parts you do not need to reprint them. Edit 2: Uploaded new easier to insert igus bearings lower file Anti_wobble_z_nut_bottom_8_8. Its otherwise identical to 8.7. This file makes it much easier to get a smooth free floating igus bearing with a resonably well dialed in printer.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

I used a 0.50mm nozzle with average layer height

Infill:

85% or better

Notes: This is a structural piece, I printed mine in ABS. PLA should work, but may not be strong enough for long term use.

Instructions You will need the following parts:
6 M5 heat set inserts http://www.mcmaster.com/#94180a361/=zhts4o
4 3/16" 1 and 3/4" long steel shafts (locally sourced from Ace Hardware)
8 Igus 2MTRI MYI-03-03 Flanged Bearing, 3/16" IDx 3/16" L (ebay)
8 1/4" threaded nylon spacers, at least 1/2" length
8 bolts that will fit the threaded nylon spacers
  • Print the replacement double bearing nut holder, Upper and lower mount block pieces x 2 (one for either side).
  • Using a 1/4" drill, gently and precisely bore out the 4 1/4" holes in the upper mount block where the nylon pins will go, using a nylon pin as a guide. it should move freely in and out, with no wobble or excess play. if it feels like it is dragging on the surface, you need to clearance it more. if it feels like it can wiggle back and forth, you need to start over and print that part again.
  • Insert the 3 heat set inserts into each half of the lower mount block. They should end up just flush with the surface.
  • Once the lower block cools off, insert 4 of the Igus bearings into their mounting holes on the tabs. There is a slight recess inside the face that the outer tabs lock into. you will probably have to compress the bearing a bit to get it to go in. Then use one of your steel 3/16" shafts to set the bearing into place and ensure it is seated properly. You should be able to smoothly move the rod back and forth in the hole, with minimal drag. if the bearing seems to bind, use a small slot head screwdriver to rotate it in the socket for a better fit.
  • Place the lower half into the upper half and insert the smooth rods. Friction on the end pieces will hold the rods in place.
  • Remove the stock Z bearing holder from your Taz. It can be helpfull to temporarily remove the leadscrew as well at this point. Retain the M5 bolts for the leadscrew as well.
  • Line the new Z nut mount up in the same location the old one was at, then install the 4 nylon posts and bolts. They will self center in the holes. Ensure they are down and tight, but not so tight that the bases mushroom out. .
  • Bolt the leadscrew nut to the heat set inserts using the stock M5 bolt hardware.
  • Swap the Double bearing holder for the new unit. Make sure the smaller tabs are down towards the heat bed. Reuse the stock bearings and hardware.
    • Your Z nuts will stick down lower than they did before this upgrade, but there should be enough room for them to fit. You should not have to modify anything else. Happy Printing!

comments.text: The stainless ones should work if nothing else. You may have to adjust the diameter, and it may be worth the time to put them in a drill chuck and run them against some 3000 grit sandpaper to polish the outside as well. The nylon spacer holes are designed for the pre-threaded variant, and you will get mushrooming with the smooth internal kind. The only fix for those is to tap them out, or order the threaded ones. if you have an ace hardware local to you, they often carry them in the hardware section. You can also get the 1 inch long spacers, use one end of the spacer to grip and turn it in, then cut it flush with a hacksaw or something similar that will make a clean cut (maybe a hobby razor saw?)

comments.text: thanks for the reply!  my ace hardware only had the unthreaded ones :(   i'll try the steel spacers first (polishing is a great idea), and then tap the nylon spacers if those fail.  i also felt the 3/16 rod i used for the y-travel could use a polish, so i'll do those at the same time.

title: EF Mount Module to 1.25 inch telescope focuser

description.text:
EDIT 2016: Check out MementoMori's remix @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1732234 Simple modification of this great EF mount. Thank you, AlexEnglish!
I did not believe it at first, but it really does fit tightly. With this you can take photos through any telescope, as long as you reach focus (No problem with a 102/1300 Maksutov, could not get in far enough on a 76/300 newton-dobson though). These adapters usually cost €20 ($28) from a telescope shop, and this probably 5% or less, depending on material, support and setting. The Mak does have a T2 mount, but for using a barlow, this is a quick and inexpensive solution! :-) Needs fixing in the future:
Spacer, so tightening the tube into the focuser is easier (now the focuser screws are pressing directly against the EF mount disc) (Sidenote for the DailyEarring project: It'll be back. Sorry for the hiatus. In the mean time, enjoy the printer live-cam at http://up.no-ip.org:8888 untill my site is back up :-) )

UPDATE 2016: Check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1732234 UPDATE NOTE 4.JULY 2012:
2- Future ideas: Ad a tube at the base of the 1.25" so the telescope does not rest against the camera mount, else tightening the telescope eyepiece screws is tedious.
1- For dailight use (450D on a Skylux 70/700 refractor) I painted the white part on the top disk and inside the small tube with a "Nail Polish Matte" (ebay ~Ã¢âÂ¬3) but any other laquer should work. Without the contrast and sharpness suffers greatly. Attention! Achtung!
When printing on an pp3dp UP, scale to [[[ 0.99 ]]], else it will not fit!
My first print did not, and I was affraid it would damage my EF mount...
Then I printed it successfully with 0.3mm layer and FAST setting (usualy I use fine/0.2mm), and oriented the 1.25" tube upwards... Needs fixing in the future:
Spacer, so tightening the tube into the focuser is easier (now the focuser screws are pressing directly against the EF mount disc) Other Ideas:
-turn around for more support material but smoother EF mount).
-Use black ABS or paint black (nailpolish...) to avoid ambient light problems On a Cupcake you may want to print the thing in two parts and glue it together, but I don't really have a clue. Please share your experiance

description.text:
Although the original version by HPaul is great, I've tried to simplify it further.  I've made just two stands - one left and one right - with deep channels.  Also as I use foamboard for other projects, I have incorporated features that allow the stands to slide onto 5mm thick foamboard.  Of course it can be used on anything that's 5mm thick.  I use foam sheet as the background which is soft enough to slide in without any tension. 
UPDATE: I have created a further centre support - with integral foamboard clip - that can be positioned anywhere between the two end stops, to give added support when a large background sheet is used.  This centre support uses the same radius as the back radius on the end stops, so they are all in alignment with each other.

title: Carl Calabria's MarkForged Composite Tensioner Jig

description.text:
During the production review meeting yesterday, October 22nd, one of the issues raised was that the composite spool tensioners were being irregularly aligned in new Mark One composite 3D printers. This doesn't degrade the performance of the printer but does significantly impact the aesthetics. Like Steve Jobs, we believe every component matters even the invisible or infrequently seen parts.
Carl Calabria decided it would be easy to create a jig for aligning the tensioners. As the Mark One is the best tool, jig and fixture printer on the market it follow that we would design and print our own tensioner alignment jig.
Carl used OnShape to CAD the holder. It was imported into Eiger, the MarkForged software, and continuous carbon fiber reinforcement was added. This would provide stiffness and strength for the inevitable drops and bumps that were sure to impact the jig in the production facility

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6Kmn0w3Jr3t

A pineapple eye remover, for use with two X-ACTO blades.
Many people are not aware that the eyes of a pineapple are laid out in spirals, not randomly. This means that, with the proper tool, you can remove the skin and then quickly remove the eyes with minimal wasted food without needing to individually core out the eyes.
If you have access to a 3D printer though, why buy a custom tool for the job when you could print it instead? 
As designed, the blades can be mounted using 2-56 screws or superglued into their recesses. You may notice there is a slight asymmetry in the design: this is to ensure a clean, complete cut at the appropriate depth.

author: flipperdescaut

description.text:
It seems that everyone uses 50mm fans, it just so happens that i have a dozen or so 35mm fans laying about. Smaller the better in my mind. No need to over do it.
There are many mounts included in other parts, and i wanted to use my smaller fans in those locations.
I'm currently using an arcol.hu hot end which i like very much. I think the design is great. It has a thermal break (PEEK) and even a simple heatsink on the cool end. even so, i've had some heat related failures about an hour or so into some big prints. Even with the heatsink, heat starts to creep up, though the hotend itself and also through the extruded material. having an extruder jam an hour into a big print is one of the most frustrating of failures, am i right?
I needed to mount one of my fans and i could have blue-taped it and been effective, but why not keep it clean? This mount uses two of the mount holes for a 50mm fan and positions and directs the fan where i need it. 
I uploaded two versions, one offset, for my particular use, and a centered version which would work fine in most cases. 
now the heatsink stays ice-cold (room temp really, poetic license, sue me) and i haven't had a heat related failure since.

Mounts simply enough. 
I included some nut traps, but i also undersized the holes so an M3 bolt should thread into the plastic. i figured if anyone stripped out the holes, or their printer effed the holes and a drill was necessary, the nut traps would be appreciated. win win.
also, i wired in a simple potentiometer since full blast isn't necessary or even desired. any time you constrict airflow into or out of a fan the turbulence will create noise. not only am i slightly directing the air with a nozzle i am also blowing right into an irregular surface (standoffs, wires, heatsink). if you are really unlucky you will get an annoying whistle. the pot lets you turn down the fan speed as far as it could go with constant voltage (PWM would be better, but unnecessary.) making it much quieter, yet still effective.
mount and enjoy.

title: Mano Libre - The Rapid Hybrid Prosthetic Forearm
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Mano Libre solves the problem of resource scarcity in prosthetics clinics around the world, especially in the developing world where 80% of amputees live. It was conceptualized, designed, executed, and delivered to a patient in 48 hours by a team of engineers and prosthetists in rural Guatemala. The Mano Libre:

  • is a standarized, cheap forearm piece to be used in a upper extremity prosthesis. It attaches directly to the elbow on the upper end, and directly to the wrist on the lower end

  • will drastically reduces the time it takes to construct an upper extremity prosthesis

  • uses less than $10 in raw materials to construct, making it much cheaper than the traditional method of fabrication

  • is much lighter and therefore easier to manipulate than traditional models
    • Traditionally, this component is fabricated by creating a cardboard tube to fill with plaster to make a mold of this piece. The mold is modified by a prosthetist before a sheet of plastic is heated and pulled over the mold. The plastic then cools, is cut off of the mold with an air saw, and then ground to size and smoothed.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Design Iterations Following the shape of the traditional forearm, I first created the tapered tube that would fit both the circumferences of the elbow and the wrist. It was a very simple model. From there, working with prosthetists from various clinics in the US, we learned the added value of a 2.5 inch extension of tubing near the wrist so that the forearm could be fit and cut down to a perfect length for each patient. At the elbow cuff location, slots were designed to match the metal saddle extensions from the elbow. Pins were added to fit in the pre-cut holes in the elbow so that the elbow sits inside the printed forearm and locks into place. The U-shaped cut was added to the design after the first print was done without it. This cut allows the user full flexion and extension of their prosthetic elbow without hitting the forearm. Another thing we decided to edit was the fill density of the print. Due to time constraints, the first print was 20% infill that we fit with a patient and it worked well. However, for heavy lifting or stronger forces, we believe that the time it takes to print the forearm in 100% infill is worth it. For prototyping an arm with the intention of lamination of a final product, a 20% or even 10% infill is sufficient. The upwards extensions on both sides of the forearm were added most recently, to allow for attachment of the cable housing running from the upper arm and the harness to the hook. In this design, there are two of these extension tabs so that the arm can be used on either a left or right arm. The unused tab can be cut off of the arm. The first design with the pin extension for the cable housing was too weak, so reinforcements were added along the walls of the forearm where it's exposed to the stress of the elbow saddle.

This is a 3d printable bracket designed to allow you to use Ridgid brand 18V lithium batteries from their cordless power tool series as portable power for projects.
Ridgid brand batteries with internal battery management, short circuit protection, overdischarge protection, rugged case, and electronic fuel gauge provide a safer means of lithium power for projects where weight constraints aren't as critical as safety.
Note: Requires Ridgid replacement part 270015155

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4

Infill:

0.2-0.5

Notes:
  • Left and right halves - print with support
  • Top plate - print flat
  • Gusset plates - print 2 mirrored versions (flat side on print bed)
  • Rail block - print flat

Step 1 - Print Print components as per print settings - high infill is not necessary, but should not negatively impact performance. Step 2 - Assemble
  • Clean support material on left/right halves
  • Press-fit 1/4"-20 and M3 nuts (tolerances may be tight for press-fit nuts) into top left and right halves, and rail block.
  • Connect leads to battery connector (Ridgid replacement part 270015155)
  • Insert battery connector into large slot facing forward (narrower end of battery) on left and right halves of the assembly
  • Loosely secure top halves to bottom rail block with M3 screws
  • Thread M3 SHCS through sides of rails with socket head facing inward, secure on outside with gusset plates.
  • Connect gusset plates to top halves with M3 SHCS
  • Remove M3 screws holding top halves to bottom rail, place top lid on, secure with M3 screws
  • Tighten all screws, test fit and adjust as necessary.

Electrical Cautions 18V battery has nominal 20.5VDC falling to 18VDC when discharged. Provide appropriate gauge wires when connecting to the battery as high current output is available from the battery, and normal battery output can exceed current capability of wiring or circuitry. For safety add some means of fault current protection (fuse, PTC fuse/polyfuse, breaker). No responsibility is assumed for this device, build and use at your own risk.

comments.text: Any chance you could modify this for older Ridgid batteries? Looking at your 2nd pic, the right side where the battery angles up to the rail portion is where they are different. The older ones go straight up, vs being cut at a 45 degree angle. I think all that needs to change is in RBBmk1-_rails, remove the angled part and print a little less material in the channel area. I hope this doesn't make the corners less stable, but it what is needed for the older batteries (and maybe why they changed the design). Thanks either way, for at least making this.

remixed_from.title: Printrbot Plus Vert. Shaft Extruder Mount for Bowden

description.text:
This is a shaft mount for a Bowden style extruder for the Printrbot Jr.  There are two files here.  
The PrintrbotJrBowdenToExtruderShaftMount.stl includes the features necessary to attach a pneufit adapter and the other doesn't.  I had already printed and glued my pneufit adapter into my thing 90335, and didn't want to take it out and glue it into a new one.  The other file just has a hole for the adapter to fit through.  
You can mount the extruder in either direction, but it would probably be better to mount it in the opposite way as shown in the picture to make it easier to change/add filament.  Mine is an older version that is too short to mount it the other way, and I haven't yet printed out the updated one.

title: Lase Pro laser cut SMART Air Nozzle

description.text:
Laser cutting can be implemented comprehensively in a wide variety of applications when working with the LaserPro engravers. Along with Acrylic (most commonly used), some of our customers also use this series to cut paper and textile. However, during and/or after laser cutting; the flaming effect will result in charred edges and affect the output quality. In order to resolve this charred edge concern, will introduce the Nozzle in an attempt to eliminate this dilemma.
In the event of flame-up or charring, the nozzle will enable a concentrated airflow that gives immediate blast to expel dust build-up or particle byproducts.

Nozzle: An optional item,recommended for cutting textile.It reduces the char and leaves a clean product surface.
With the enlarged picture, you can see the differences after using Fine Nozzle.
Tips:
Do not function the Auto Focus when using Fine Nozzle/Ultra Nozzle. Please use the focus gauge instead of relying on the Auto Focus to avoid hitting on the table. Adjust airflow according to the materials used.Not all materials can be processed with the strongest airflow. LaserPro Venus II
LaserPro Mercury III
GCC LaserPro Spirit
LaserPro Explorer
LaserPro Spirit GX
GCC LaserPro C180
LaserPro S290

author: bonleo

description.text: The P3Steel is possibly one of the better Prusa based printer designs. I recently converted my i3 single plate to a P3Steel frame and I am really pleased. It's not all roses and champagne though - the Y Axis smooth rods are push fit into the steel plate and aren't held in place tightly. There are a few parts already on thingiverse but they were binding with the thumb screws on the bed. Here is my solution - some clamps for 8mm smooth rods that use an M3 bolt and Nylon nuts to really hold right onto it. Put them on the inside pushed right up tight to the steel plate at either end and tighten up the bolts. Should hold them firmly enough! Protip: print at 0.2mm layer height to make sure you get a well defined round hole and nut trap.

description.text:
So the inevitable happened and one of my very long prints warped, causing the head to crash and snapped the auto leveling sensor bracket. Luckily I managed to get it glued back together to run a few prints. 
Being in IT I managed to get a friend from the Drawing Office to do me a 3D file in Solidworks to replace it. (I had just updated all their systems and had it installed for them).  Thanks Ian Stratford. One of our 3D gurus. The original was also printed, by the way.
This bracket is a little chunkier, and holds the sensor more tightly. Not a bad thing. It may even get away with not needing the tightening screw. 
I was back up and running in under 24 hours. Waiting for the replacement here in the UK could have been frustrating.
Remember, print 2!

comments.text: It is just  a little chunkier and the point at which mine snapped, by the arm coming back down to the recess for the longer screw head, is curved to allow for more support. The original is thinner at that point and goes straight into that part and so has slightly less strength.
comments.author: Gruffest

title: Galaxy S3, S4, LG G2 & More Dock V2.0 - CASE COMPATIBLE

description.text:
UPDATE:
Adding "fixed" versions of the STL to resolve issues with some slicers. This is an updated version of:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52959 There are four variations derived from two options.
  • Minimalist VS Full Stand
  • Original and Steep Slope
    • What's new:
  • Longer base for added stability.
  • Front cutout for easy home button operation.
  • New cable management design.
  • New "minimalist" design option.
  • New steeper slope option.
  • Cleaner look.
  • Optional clip to help keep the phone in place.

Requirements:
  • Hot Glue Gun
  • Micro USB Cable (you won't be getting it back)
  • Tape
    • Build Instructions:
  • You may need to scale the object to 25.4 if you are using the STL.
  • If you are going to use a VERY thick case (like an OtterBox) scale the object by either ??? or ??? (sorry, need measurements, please send).
  • == Print == -

    Optional But Recommended Step:

  • I recommend putting at least three coats of PlastiDip on the bottom on the dock. Check to make sure the dock still sits level between coats. It REALLY makes it stick nice!!!
  • Feed the cable though the front hole on the bottom of the stand and connect it to your phone with the case on.
  • Seat the phone tightly in the stand and confirm fit.
  • NOTE: If it is too tight or too loose, you need to fix it now!
  • Firmly tape the phone down (this is where your phone will sit when docked).
  • Secure the stand on the edge of a table.
  • From the bottom, use the hot glue gun to secure the USB cable in place. Use a lot, but try not to get any on the cable it self (you will need to bend it back later).
    NOTE: It is ok to get some glue on the base of the phones case, but be careful; if you get your phone too hot you could damage it!
  • Double check the phones seating, this is your last chance to adjust it.
  • Let it cool for at lease 5 minutes! Seriously, don't rush it!
  • Hold the cable taunt so it doesn't drop below the stands base.
  • Use more hot glue to secure the cable in this position.
  • Again, let the glue harden.
    • Clips:
    If you are going to use the clips, they should each be printed separately for maximum quality. Once you have everything in place, a few drops of superglue in the back should do it. Leaving them un-glued in the front may make docking easier. It's up to you, give it a try either way.
